sentence: Problem and contribution:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: The paper studies if the Visual Question answering model “FILM” from Perez et al (2018) is able to decide if “most” of the objects have a certain attribute or color.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: For this it tries to mimic the setup used to test human abilities in the study by Pietroski et al. (2009).
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The main contribution of this is work is a discussion of how a model could solve the problem of deciding “most” and the study which shows that the studied model has some ability to do this.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: From this the paper concludes that the model is likely to have some approximate number system.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Strengths:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: 1.	The paper looks at a new angle to study and characterize CNN models in general, and VQA models in particular by looking into the psycholinguistic literature experimental setup studied with human subjects.
label: none

sentence: 2.	The paper studies different variants of controlling for different factors (e.g. pairing data points, area used, different training data and pre-trained vs. trained from scratch CNN models)
label: none

sentence: 3.	It is interesting to see that the models performance reasonably aligns with the curve predicted by “Weber’s law”.
label: none

sentence: Weaknesses:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: 4.	Number of objects vs. ratios is not disentangled: While the paper clarifies that not only a smaller number of objects are used, it would be interesting to understand if similar conclusions hold if only the same number or about the same number of total objects are used but the ratios change (at least for more extreme ratios, 1:2, this seems to be the case as they achieve 100% accuracy).
label: arg-request_experiment

sentence: The paper only focusses on a single VQA model (FILM) which limits the understanding if this observation is specific to this model; what about other models such as the one from Hudson & Manning (2018), or Relation Networks (Santoro et al) or even simpler baselines: A system which two attention mechanisms (without normalizations) which are sum pooled and then compared would sort of explicitly encode the idea of the APN system.
label: none

sentence: It would be valuable to compare them to see how different systems (can) solve this task.
label: arg-request_experiment

sentence: I would expect that the architecture favors certain capabilities; e.g. Relation Networks might lead more to a paring-based strategy. Or Zhang et al. (2018) might be able to exploit explicit counting to solve the task.
label: none

sentence: 6.	The “most” ability or APN ability seems to be highly related to accumulation in neural networks.
label: none

sentence: The paper FiLM uses global max-pooling and I am wondering if this affect this ability.
label: arg-request_clarification

sentence: 7.	The study is only performed on symbols which a very large training set (given the difficulty of the problem) and it not clear how well this generalizes to real images or scenarios with less training data.
label: none

sentence: Maybe beyond the scope of this work, but it would be interesting to understand how much training data different models need to obtain this capability.
label: arg-request_experiment

sentence: 8.	For evaluation: Are there distractors, i.e. elements which don’t belong to set A or B? If not, how would distractors affect it.

sentence: This paper proposes an additional loss term to use when training an LSTM LM.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The authors argue that, intuitively, we want the output distribution to retain some information about the context, or "past".
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Given this, they use the output distribution as input to a one layer network that must predict the current token.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The loss for this network is incorporated as an additional term used when training the LM.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The authors show that by adding this loss term they can achieve SOTA (for single softmax model) perplexity on a number of LM benchmarks.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The technical contribution is proposing a new loss term to use when training a language model.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The idea is clear, simple, and well explained, and it seems to be effective in practice.
label: none

sentence: One drawback is that it is highly specific to language models.
label: none

sentence: Other recent works which have demonstrated effective regularization of LSTM LMs have proposed methods that can be used in any LSTM model, but that is not the case here.
label: none

sentence: In addition, there is not much theoretical justification for it, it seems like a one-off trick.
label: none

sentence: The loss term is motivated by the idea that we want the output distribution to retain some information about the context, but why should that be the case?
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: Although it is specific to language models, there are a few reasons it might be of broader significance:
label: none

sentence: - It falls in the recent line of work in incorporating auxiliary losses for various tasks.
label: none

sentence: This idea has touched many problems and seen success in practice.
label: none

sentence: - Perhaps it can be applied to other sequence models.
label: arg-request_experiment

sentence: For example in encoder-decoder models, the decoder can be thought of as a conditional LM.
label: none

sentence: Experiments are comprehensive and rigorous.
label: none

sentence: They might be more convincing if there were results on a very large corpus such as 1 billion word corpus.

sentence: The main idea behind the paper is to use random projections as the initial word representations, rather than the vocab-size 1-hot representations, as is usually done in language modeling.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The benefit is that the matrix which projects words into embedding space can then be much smaller, since the space of random projections can be much smaller than the vocab size.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The idea is an interesting one, but
label: none

sentence: this work is at too much of a preliminary stage for a top-tier conference such as ICLR. In its present state it would make for a potentially interesting paper at a targeted workshop.
label: none

sentence: More specific comments
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: The initial description of the language modeling problem assumes a particular decomposition of the joint probability, according to a particular application of the chain rule, but of course this is a modeling choice and not the only option (albeit the standard one).
label: none

sentence: The main problem with the paper is the use of simple baseline setups as the only experimental configuration:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: o feedforward rather than recurrent network;
label: none

sentence: o use of the Penn Treebank dataset only;
label: none

sentence: o use of a small n for the n-grams.
label: none

sentence: All or at least some of these decisions would need to be relaxed to make a convincing paper.
label: none

sentence: The reasons for the use of the energy-based formulation are not clear to me.
label: none

sentence: Is the energy-based model particularly well-suited to the random-projection setup, or are there other reasons for using it, independent of the use of random projections?
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: Just before equation 6 it says that the resulting vector representation is the *sum* of all the non-zero entries.
label: none

sentence: But there are some minus ones in the random projection?
label: none

sentence: The PPL expression at the bottom of p.5 doesn't look right.
label: none

sentence: The index over which the sum happens is n, but n is fixed? So this looks like a sum with just one component in it, namely the first n-gram.
label: arg-request_clarification

sentence: It looks like all the results are given on the test set. Did you not do any tuning on the validation data?
label: arg-request_clarification

sentence: The plots in figure 4 are too small.
label: none

sentence: It would be useful to have a table, like the one on the last page, which clearly shows the baseline vs. the random-projection model, with some description of the results in the main body of the text.
label: arg-request_result

sentence: The overall presentation could be better, and I would encourage the authors to tidy the paper up in any subsequent submission.
label: none

sentence: For example, there are lots of typos such as "instead of trying to probability of a target word".
label: arg-request_typo

sentence: This work proposes a hybrid VAE-based model (combined with an adversarial or maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) based loss) to perform timbre transfer on recordings of musical instruments.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Contrary to previous work, a single (conditioned) decoder is used for all instrument domains, which means a single model can be used to convert any source domain to any target domain.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Unfortunately, the results are quite disappointing in terms of sound quality, and feature many artifacts.
label: none

sentence: The instruments are often unrecognisable, although with knowledge of the target domain, some of its characteristics can be identified.
label: none

sentence: The many-to-many results are clearly better than the pairwise results in this regard, but in the context of musical timbre transfer, I don't feel that this model successfully achieves its goal -- the results of Mor et al. (2018), although not perfect either, were better in this regard.
label: none

sentence: I have several further concerns about this work:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: * The fact that the model makes use of pitch class and octave labels also raises questions about applicability -- if I understood correctly, transfer can only be done when this information is present.
label: none

sentence: I think the main point of transfer over a regular generative model that goes from labels to audio is precisely that it can be done without label information.
label: none

sentence: * The use of fully connected layers also implies that it requires fixed length input, so windowing and stitching are necessary for it to be applied to recordings of arbitrary length. Why not train a convolutional model instead?
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: * I think the choice of a 3-dimensional latent space is poorly justified. Why not use more dimensions and project them down to 3 for visualisation and interpetation purposes with e.g. PCA or t-SNE?
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: This seems like an unnecessary bottleneck in the model, and could partly explain the relatively poor quality of the results.
label: none

sentence: I appreciated that the one-to-one transfer experiments are incremental comparisons, which provides valuable information about how much each idea contributes to the final performance.
label: none

sentence: Overall, I feel that this paper falls short of what it promises, so I cannot recommend acceptance at this time.
label: none

sentence: Other comments:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: * In the introduction, an adversarial criterion is referred to as a "discriminative objective", but "adversarial" (i.e. featuring a discriminator) and "discriminative" mean different things. I don't think it is correct to refer to an adversarial criterion as discriminative.
label: arg-request_edit

sentence: * Also in the introduction, it is implied that style transfer constitutes an advance in generative models, but style transfer does not make use of / does not equate to any generative model.
label: none

sentence: * Some turns of phrase like "recently gained a flourishing interest", "there is still a wide gap in quality of results", "which implies a variety of underlying factors", ... are vague / do not make much sense and should probably be reformulated to enhance readability.
label: arg-request_edit

sentence: * Introduction, top of page 2: should read "does not learn" instead of "do not learns".
label: arg-request_typo

sentence: * Mor et al. (2018) do actually make use of an adversarial training criterion (referred to as a "domain confusion loss"), contrary to what is claimed in the introduction.
label: arg-request_edit

sentence: * The claim that training a separate decoder for each domain necessarily leads to prohibitive training times is dubious -- a single conditional decoder would arguably need more capacity than each individual separate decoder model.
label: none

sentence: I think all claims about running time should be corroborated by controlled experiments.
label: arg-request_experiment

sentence: * I think Figure 1 is great and helps a lot to distinguish the different domain translation paradigms.
label: none

sentence: * I found the description in Section 3.1 a bit confusing as it initially seems that the approach requires paired data (e.g. "matching samples").
label: none

sentence: * Section 3.1, "amounts to optimizing" instead of "amounts to optimize"
label: arg-request_typo

sentence: * Higgins et al. (2016) specifically discuss the case where beta in formula (1) is larger than one.
label: none

sentence: As far as I can tell, beta is annealed from 0 to 1 here, which is an idea that goes back to "Generating Sentences from a Continuous Space" by Bowman et al. (2016).
label: none

sentence: This should probably be cited instead.
label: arg-request_edit

sentence: * "circle-consistency" should read "cycle-consistency" everywhere.
label: arg-request_typo

sentence: * MMD losses in the context of GANs have also been studied in the following papers:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: - "Training generative neural networks via Maximum Mean Discrepancy optimization", Dziugaite et al. (2015)
label: none

sentence: - "Generative Models and Model Criticism via Optimized Maximum Mean Discrepancy", Sutherland et al. (2016)
label: none

sentence: - "MMD GAN: Towards Deeper Understanding of Moment Matching Network", Li et al. (2017)
label: none

sentence: * The model name "FILM-poi" is only used in the "implementation details" section, it doesn't seem to be referred to anywhere else. Is this a typo?
label: arg-request_clarification

sentence: * The differences between UNIT (GAN; C-po) and UNIT (MMD; C-po) in Table 1 seem very small and I'm not convinced that they are significant. Why does the MMD version constitute an improvement? Or is it simply more stable to train?
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: * The descriptor distributions in Figure 3 don't look like an "almost exact match" to me (as claimed in the text).
label: none

sentence: There are some clearly visible differences.
label: none

sentence: I think the wording is a bit too strong here.
label: none

sentence: I believe that the authors have a solid contribution that can be interesting for the ICLR community.
label: none

sentence: Therefore, I recommend to accept the paper but after revision because the presentation and explanation of the ideas contain multiple typos and lacking some details (see bellow).
label: none

sentence: Summary:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: The authors propose a new method called BA-Net to solve the SfM problem by explicitly incorporating geometry priors into a machine learning task.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The authors focus on the Bundle Adjustment process.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Given several successive frames of a video sequence (2 frames but can be extended up to 5), BA-Net jointly estimates the depth of the first frame and the relative camera motion (between the first frame and the next one).
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The method is based on a convolutional neural network which extracts the features of the different pyramid levels of the two images and in parallel computes the depth map of the first frame.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The proposed network is based on the DRN-54 (Yu et al., 2017) as a feature extractor.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: This is complemented by the linear combination of depth bases obtained from the first image.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The features and the initial depth then passed to the optimization layer called BA-layer where the feature re-projection error is minimized by the modified LM algorithm.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The authors adapt the standard multi-view geometry constraints by a new concept of feature re-projection error in the BA framework (BA-layer) which they made differentiable.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Differentiable optimization of camera motion and image depth via LM algorithm is now possible and can be used in various other DL architectures (ex. MVS-Net can probably benefit from BA-layer).
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The authors also propose a novel depth parametrization in the form of linear combination of depth bases which reduces the number of parameters for the learning task,
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: enables integration into the same backbone net as used or feature pyramids and makes it possible to jointly train the depth generator and the BA-layer.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Originally the proposed approach depicts the network operating in the two-view settings.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The extensibility to more views is also possible and, as shown by authors, proved to improve performance.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: It is, however, limited by the GPU capacity.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Overall, the authors came up with an interesting approach to the standard BA problem.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: They have managed to inject the multi-view geometry priors and BA into the DL architecture.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Major comments regarding the paper:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: It would be interesting to know the evaluation times for the BA-net and more importantly to have some implementation details to ensure reproducibility.
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: Minor comments regarding the paper:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: -	The spacing between sections is not consistent.
label: none

sentence: -	Figures 1 is way too abstract given the complicated set-up of the proposed architecture.
label: none

sentence: It would be nice to see more details on the subnet for depth estimator and output of the net.
label: arg-request_result

sentence: Overall it would be helpful for reproducibility if authors can visualize all the layers of all the different parts of the network as it is commonly done in the DL papers.
label: arg-request_edit

sentence: Talking about proposed formulation of BA use either of the following and be consistent across the paper:
label: none

sentence: Featuremetric BA / Feature-metric BA / Featuremetric BA / ‘Feature-metric BA’
label: none

sentence: -	Talking about depth parametrization use ‘basis’ or ‘bases’ not both and clearly defined the meaning of this important notion.
label: none

sentence: -	Attention should be given to the notation in formulas (3) and (4).
label: arg-request_edit

sentence: The projection function there is no longer accepts a 3D point parametrized by 3 variables.
label: none

sentence: Instead only depth is provided.
label: none

sentence: In addition, the subindex ‘1’ of the point ‘q’ is not explained.
label: none

sentence: -	More attention should be given to the evaluation section.
label: none

sentence: Specifically to the tables (1 and 2) with quantitative results showing the comparison to other methods.
label: none

sentence: It is not clear how the depth error is measured and it would be nicer to have the other errors explained exactly as they referred in the tables (e.g. ATE?).
label: none

sentence: -	How the first camera pose is initialized?
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: -	In Figure 2.b I’m surprised by the difference obtained in the feature maps for images which seems very similar (only the lighting seems to be different). Is it three consecutive frames?
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: -	Attention should be given to the grammar, formatting in particular the bibliography.
label: arg-request_edit

sentence: Summary.
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: The authors empirically investigate the influence of the architecture and the capacity of an NN-model on the transferability of adversarial examples.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: They also study the influence of the smoothness.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: From the obtained results, they propose the smoothed gradient attack showing improvements on the transferability of adversarial examples.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Pros.
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: * Robustness of neural nets is a challenging problem of interest for ICLR
label: none

sentence: * The paper is well written
label: none

sentence: * The experimental study is convincing
label: none

sentence: * The experimental results for the smoothed gradient attacks are promising
label: none

sentence: Cons.
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: * The results of the experimental study are somehow expected
label: none

sentence: * the idea of smoothing gradients is not new
label: none

sentence: Evaluation.
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: The experimental study of the transferability of adversarial examples is well designed.
label: none

sentence: Experimental protocol is convincing.
label: none

sentence: The smoothed gradient attacks improve many previously proposed attacks.
label: none

sentence: Therefore, my opinion is rather positive. But, as a non expert in the field, I am not completely convinced by the novelty of the approach.

label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: This paper introduces a new generative poisoning attack method against machine learning classifiers.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The authors propose pGAN with three components to maximum the error of classification and guarantee undistinguished poisoning data for the discriminator.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The experimental results show that the hyperparameter \alpha significantly affects the poisoning data distribution and pGAN leads to specific error in a classification task.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: This paper should be weekly accepted, considering the following aspects.
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: Positive points: (1) The experiments seem solid.
label: none

sentence: The overall performance with different parameters and the corresponding error type have been evaluated.
label: none

sentence: (2) The error-specific and performance-control characteristics of pGAN seem to be interesting.
label: none

sentence: (3) The paper is well organized.
label: none

sentence: Negative points: (1) The authors should provide more justification on equation-3.
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: Why do the authors directly average different loss for the discriminator and the classifer?
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: (2) The function of the discriminator is not very clear, especially for the classification error test.
label: none

sentence: Does the discriminator exclude the poisoning data according to certain rule?
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: It would make more sense if the classification error measured from the data the discriminator selects.
label: arg-request_experiment

sentence: (3) pGAN can produce error-specific attack without sufficient justifications.
label: none

sentence: Why can pGAN lead to the inclination? Is it possible for pGAN to control the specific error tendency?
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: (4) For the error-specific attack task, it would be better to provide an ablation experiment.
label: arg-request_experiment

sentence: For example, authors could implement pGAN by ignoring the detectability of the discriminator (i.e. \alpha=0) or typical pGAN when they compare with the label-flip operation.
label: arg-request_experiment

sentence: Please explain which component contribute to the error-specific inclination.
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: The paper presents proof that the DeepSets and a variant of PointNet are universal approximators for permutation equivariant functions.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The proof uses an expression for equivariant polynomials and the universality of MLP.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: It then shows that the proposed expression in terms of power-sum polynomials can be constructed in PointNet using a minimal modification to the architecture, or using DeepSets, therefore proving the universality of such deep models.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The results of this paper are important.
label: none

sentence: In terms of presentation, the notation and statement of theorems are precise, however, the presentation is rather dry, and I think the paper can be significantly more accessible.
label: none

sentence: For example, here is an alternative and clearer route presenting the same result: one may study the simple case of having single input channel, for which the output at index "i" of an equivariant polynomial is written as the sum of all powers of input multiplied by a polynomial function of the corresponding power-sum.
label: none

sentence: This second part is indeed what is used in the proof of the universality of the permutation invariant version of DeepSets, making the connection more visible.
label: none

sentence: Generalizing this to the multi-channel input as the next step could make the proof more accessible.
label: arg-request_edit

sentence: The second issue I would like to raise is related to discussions around the non-universality of the vanilla PointNet model.
label: none

sentence: Given the fact that it applies the same MLP independently to individual set members, it is obvious that it is not universal equivariant (for example, consider a function that performs a fixed permutation to its input), and I fail to see why the paper goes into the trouble of having theorems and experiments just to demonstrate this point. If there were any other objectives beyond this in the experiments could you please clarify?
label: arg-request_clarification

sentence: Finally, could you give a more accurate citation (chapter-page number) for the single-channel version of Theorem 2.?
label: arg-request_edit

sentence: The paper focuses on the stability prediction task on the ShapeStacks dataset.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Specifically, the paper creates a new extension to the dataset, and it proposes the use of "Neural Stethoscopes" framework to analyze deep neural nets' physical reasoning of local stability v.s. global stability.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: It is shown in the paper neural nets tend to be misled by local stability when the task is to predict global stability.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Then the paper utilizes the proposed framework to de-bias the misleading correlation to achieve a state-of-the-art on the dataset.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The paper is very well-written and easy to follow.
label: none

sentence: The main idea is simple and the experiments are detailed.
label: none

sentence: Specifically on the task of stability prediction, it is quite interesting to know that neural nets can be misled by visual cues (local stability).
label: none

sentence: However, my concern is that the paper focuses only on a very specific application domain,  and an improvement over the niche dataset with much more supervision (from the extension) is not surprising at all. In the mean time, the notion of "Neural Stethoscopes" could be much more  generally applied. Without applications in other domains, it is not immediately clear what the paper's implication is.
label: none

sentence: Summary:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: The authors look at the problem of exploration in deep RL.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: They propose a “curiosity grid” which is a virtual grid laid out on top of the current level/area that an Atari agent is in.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Once an agent enters a new cell of the grid, it obtains a small reward, encouraging the agent to explore all parts of the game.
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The grid is reset (meaning new rewards can be obtained) after every roll out (meaning the Atari agent has used up all its lives and the game restarts).
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: The authors argue that this method enables better exploration and they obtain an impressive score on Montezuma’s Revenge (MR).
label: arg-structuring_summary

sentence: Review:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: The paper contains an extensive introduction with many references to prior work, and a sensible lead up to the introduced algorithm.
label: none

sentence: The algorithm itself seems to work well and some of the results are convincing.
label: none

sentence: I am a bit worried about the fact that the agents have access to their history of locations (“the grid”).
label: none

sentence: The authors mention that none of the methods they compare against has this advantage and it seems that in a game that rewards exploration directly (MR) this is a large advantage.
label: none

sentence: The authors comment on this advantage in section 3 and found that removing intrinsic rewards hurt performance significantly.
label: none

sentence: Only removing the grid access made results on MR very unstable.
label: none

sentence: However in order to compute the intrinsic rewards, it still seems necessary to access the location of the agent, meaning that implicitly the advantage of the method is still there.
label: none

sentence: I was wondering if the authors find that the agents are forcibly exploring the entire environment during each rollout? Even if the agent knows what/where the actual goal is. There is a hint to this behaviour in section 4, on exploration in sparse domains.
label: arg-request_explanation

sentence: The future work section mentions some interesting improvements, where the agent position is learned from data. That seems like a promising direction that would generalise beyond Atari games and avoids the advantage.
label: none

sentence: Nits/writing feedback:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: - There is no need for such repetitive citing (esp paragraph 2 on page 2).
label: none

sentence: Sometimes the same paper is cited 4 times within a few lines.
label: none

sentence: While it’s great that so much prior work was acknowledged, mentioning a paper once per paragraph is (usually) sufficient and increases readability.
label: none

sentence: - I think the comparison between prior lifetimes and humans mastering a language doesn’t hold up and is distracting
label: none

sentence: Revision:
label: arg-structuring_heading

sentence: The rebuttal does little to clarify open questions:
label: none

sentence: 1. Both reviewer 2 and I commented on the ablation study regarding the grid but received no reply.
label: none

sentence: 2. I am not convinced this method is sufficiently new, given that there are other methods that try to directly reward visiting new states.
label: none

sentence: 3. The authors argue in their rebuttal that "the grid" is a novel idea that warrants investigation, but remark in figure 5 that likely it isn't the key aspect of their algorithm.
label: none

sentence: This seems contradictory.
label: none
